w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: [Beurla]

’ S iomadh àit a bheil cliù ort
Nach robh ’ m pàirtidh do dhùthcha ;
Sheas thu dàna gun chùram
Gun fhàilinn gun lùbadh , 480
Gu neo - sgàthach le dùrachd ,
Anns an àite bu rùn leat ,
Far ’ n a gheall thu o thùs a bhith càirdeach ,
Far ’ n a gheall &c .

’ S an am gluasaid no carraid 485
Bha thu cruadalach fearail ,
Mar bu dual duit o d ’ sheanair ,
Choisinn buaidh ann an Gallaibh ,
’ N uair a bhuannaich e ’ m fearann ;
Bha na tuathaich gun anam 490
’ N déis an ruagadh ’ s an gearradh ’ san àraich ,
’ N déis an ruagadh &c .
[Beurla]

’ S cha b ’ i ’ n eucoir a shir iad :
’ S mór t ’ fheums ’ air bhith sgileil ,
O ’ s tu fhéin a tha ’ n ionad nan àrmann ,
O ’ s tu fhéin &c . 500

Sàr cheannard gach fin ’ thu ,
Deagh mhaighstir nan gillean ,
’ S an comanndair gun tioma
An tùs aimhreit no iomairt ,
Nach dèan parladh a shireadh ; 505
Le d ’ lanntaibh geur biorach
Bhiodh calldach is iomain air nàmhaid ,
Bhiodh calldach &c .

’ S bidh do chinneadh mór fhéin leat
Anns gach cunnart an téid thu , 510
’ S iad gu fuileachdach feumail
Bhualadh bhuillean is spéicean ;
’ S lìonmhor curaidh ’ na éideadh
Bhitheas ullamh gu éirigh
An am dhuit bhith ’ g éigheach crois - tàraidh , 515
An am dhuit bhith &c .

’ S iomadh caraid mun cuairt duit
Eadar Bealach is Cruachan
Leis ’ m bu mhath thu bhith ’ n uachdar
Le neart tein ’ agus luaidhe , 520
’ S nan lann tana geur cruaidhe ,
Rachadh mar riut g ’ am bualadh ,
’ N uair a thogadh tu suaicheantas àrda ,
’ N uair a thogadh &c .
[Beurla]

Bu ghreadhnaiche tartar :
Na cinn - fheadhna ’ s na gaisgich , 530
Le maidhm bheirt ’ a mach leò buaidh - làrach ,
Le maidhm bheirt ’ &c .

Reachdmhor àrdanach mórchuis ’
Duineil ceannsalach seòlta ,
Marcach àrd nan each móra 535
Bu mhór srann ’ s bu mhath fòghlam ;
Fasan Gallda gu leòr ort ,
’ S math thig ad a ’ bhil ’ òir dhuit
Air chùl clannach bu bhòidhche measg Ghàidheal ,
Air chùl clannach &c . 540

Aghaidh mhacanta choibhneil
Mhàlda mheachair mar mhaighdean ,
Dàna smachdail mar shaighdear ;
Cridhe soilleir gun fhoill
Anns a ’ chom as glaine na ’ n daoimean ; 545
T ’ aigneadh uile le soillse
Mar ghrian choibhneil a ’ boillsgeadh air fàire ,
Mar ghrian choibhneil &c .

Suairce sìobhalta fearail ,
Sùil lìontach ghorm mheallach 550
Bu chaol fìnealta mala ;
Gruaidh ghrìsdhearg channach ,
Beul bìth a bu taine ,
Cneas mìngheal mar chanach :
Chan ’ eil tì a thug barrachd air t ’ àilleachd , 555
Chan ’ eil tì a thug &c .
[Beurla]

Bu rìomhach do dhiùtaidh ,
Bhith càradh a ’ chrùin
Air an rìgh ’ g a bheil dùthchas an àite ,
Air an rìgh ’ g a bheil &c .

Sàr chùirtear na maise , 565
’ G an robh cliù air gach fasan ,
Fhuair iùl ann an Sasainn
Air na cùiseannaibh tagraidh ,
’ S e do thùr a bha beachdail ;
Tha ’ n dùthaich làn aitis 570
On thàinig thu dhachaigh le fàilte ,
On thàinig thu &c .

Sàr phòitear an fhìon ’ thu ,
’ S tu dh ’ òladh ’ s a dhìoladh ;
Fhuair thu fòghlam gach rìoghachd , 575
Meòir as grinne nì sgrìobhadh ;
Bu tu sealgair na sìdhne
Le d ’ chuilbheir caol dìreach ,
’ N uair a thàrladh tu ’ m frìth nam beann àrda ,
’ N uair a thàrladh &c . 580

An am dhuit bhith tadhal
Anns a ’ bheinn am bi ’ n fhaghailt ,
Leat bu mhiannach a ’ ghreadhain ,
Fuaim mhiosar ri h - adhairc ,
Gunna - glaice do roghainn , 585
Gairm ghalanaich gadhair ,
’ N uair a rachadh e ’ n deaghaidh fir cràice ,
’ N uair a rachadh &c .
[Beurla]

Ri h - eilid na stùice ,
’ S bhiodh a ceithreannan brùite ,
Is do ghillean ’ ga giùlan a fàsach , 595
Is do ghillean &c .

’ S ’ n uair a theàrnte gu d ’ bhaile
Mu oidhche le faram ,
Bu ghleadhrach an talla ,
Tùr greadhnach sin Bhealaich ; 600
Mór choibhneas air t ’ aire ,
Bhiodh loinn air luchd - ealaidh
Leis an seinnte gach caithreim a b ’ àill leat ,
Leis an seinnte &c .

Mu chromadh na gréine 605
’ N uair a dhonnadh na speuran ,
Gheibhte sollain is éibhneas
An taigh soilleir na féile ,
Gach ceòl bu bhinne r ’ an éisdeachd
Comh - fhreagairt a chéile — 610
An fhidheall ’ s na teudan ’ s a ’ chlàrsach
An fhidheall ’ s na teudan &c .

Madainn shoilleir ag éirigh ,
Gheibhte chomaine cheudna :
Pìob am follais ’ ga spéiceadh , 615
Feadain loma ’ gan gleusadh ,
Dosa donna ri beus daibh —
Ceòl loinneil bu réidhe ,
Sìor chaitheamh na féisd ann ad àros ,
Sìor chaitheamh &c . 620

’ S i an trompaid ’ s na h - orgain
Bu ghlan pronndal is monmhor ;
’ N uair a lomte gach corrmheur
Nach bu trom air an t - sorchan
Bu phongail an torman , 625
Gu fonnmhorach foirmeil ,
Ann an teaghlach a ’ mhormhair ri àbhachd ,
Ann an teaghlach &c .
[Beurla]

Talla flathasach rìoghail
An robh mathas gun mhìorun , 630
Gheibht ’ ann tathaich gu lìonmhor
De mhaithibh na rìoghachd ,
Seòl air caitheamh an fhìona ,
Uisge - beath ’ ann am pìosan ,
A ’ sìor ghabhail sìos nan deoch - slàinte , 635
A ’ sìor ghabhail &c .

Mar bu mhiannach leat fhaicinn ,
Bhith gu fialaidh mar chleachd thu ,
Miosail miadhail gun airceas ;
Uaisl ’ is rìomhadh is fasan , 640
Or lìonmhor ’ ga sgapadh ,
Cluiche dian ’ ga chur seachad
Air dhìsnean , air chairtibh ’ s air thàileasg ,
Air dhìsnean , air chairtibh &c .

Beus nach b ’ ainneamh le d ’ theaghlach , 645
Bhith gu faramach greadhnach ,
Ceòl is aiteas gach oidhche ,
Seòmar laiste le coinnlibh ;
’ S e Gleann Urchaidh do staoidhle ,
’ S tu air Bealach ad oighre , 650
Gu meal thu do ghreim air an àite ,
Gu meal thu do ghreim &c .

A Dhòmhnaill Bhàin Mhic O Neachdain
Tha ’ n droch nàdur ad phearsain ;
Cha ghnàthaich thu ’ n ceartas
Gus am bàsaich thu ’ n pheacadh ;
’ S mairg àit anns ’ n a thachair 1305
Am ball - sampaill gun chneasdachd ,
A rinn gràineil an sgaiteachd ud òirnn ,
A rinn gràineil &c .

Fhir a thòisich ri ealaidh ,
Bha thu gòrach ad bharail , 1310
’ Ga seòladh am charaibh ,
’ S gun mi t ’ fheòraich no t ’ fharraid ;
Chuir thu sgleò dhìot is fanaid :
Co dhiùbh ’ s deòin leat no ’ s aindeoin ,
Tha mi ’ n dòchas gum faigh thu do leòr , 1315
Tha mi ’ n dòchas &c .

Dhomh - sa b ’ aithne do bheusan :
Tha thu aineolach beumnach ,
Is do theanga mar reusar
Le tainead ’ s le géiread ; 1320
Thug thu deannal domh fhéin dith ;
O ’ s ann agad tha ’ n eucoir ,
Cuim ’ nach pàighinn thu ’ n éirig do sgeòil ?
Cuim ’ nach pàighinn &c .
[Beurla]

Stoc thu togairt do ’ n ghrìosaich ,
A thoill do losgadh mar ìobairt , 1330
Leig thu ’ n soisgeul air dìochuimhn gu mór ,
Leig thu ’ n soisgeul &c .

Bu bheag an diùbhail e thachairt
An latha thùr thu na facail ,
Dà phunnd agus cairteal 1335
A dh ’ fhùdar cruaidh sgairteil
A bhith ad bhroinn air a chalcadh ,
’ S bhith ’ gad sgàineadh le maitse ,
Gus am fàsadh tu ’ d ablach gun deò ,
Gus am fàsadh &c . 1340

’ S blianach righinn gun fheum thu ;
Ged a bhitheadh tu ’ m féithe ,
Coin is fithich ad theumadh ,
Cha bhiodh an dìol béidh ac ’ .
’ S tric thu teann air na h - éibhlean , 1345
Bhreac do shuimeir gu t ’ éislich ,
Blàth an tein ’ air do shléisdibh gu mór ,
Blàth an tein ’ &c .

O nach tàillear as fhiù thu ,
Chuir càch as a ’ chùirt thu ; 1350
Bidh tu ghnàth anns na cùiltean
A ’ càradh nan lùireach ;
Bu tu àsainn nan clùdan ,
’ S tric a shuidh thu ’ san smùraich
’ N uair a bhithinn - s ’ air cùl fir nan cròc , 1355
’ N uair a bhithinn - s ’ &c .

’ S e do choltas r ’ a ìnnseadh ,
Fear sopcheannach grìmeach ,
Gun bhonaid gun phìorbhuic ,
Gun bhad - mullaich gun chìrean , 1360
Lom uil ’ air a spìonadh ;
Càrr gu t ’ uilinn a sìos ort ,
Stràc na dunach de ’ n sgrìobaich mu d ’ cheòs ,
Stràc na dunach &c .
[Beurla]

’ S iomadh àit anns ’ n a thachair 1365
An tàillear Mac Neachdain
Eadar Albainn is Sasainn ,
Bailtean margaidh is machair ;
’ S tric a shealg thu air praisich :
O nach d ’ fhalbh thu le clapa , 1370
Chaoidh cha mharbh e duin ’ aca de ’ n t - slògh ,
Chaoidh cha mharbh &c .

’ S duine dona gun mhios thu
Dh ’ fhàs gun onoir gun ghliocas ;
Fear gun chomas gun bhriosgadh , 1375
Chaill do spionnadh ’ s do mhisneach
Leis na rinn thu de ’ n bhidseachd ;
Bu tu ’ n slaidhtire misgeach ,
’ S cian on thoill thu do chuipeadh mu ’ n òl ,
’ S cian on thoill &c . 1380

’ S iomadh ceapaire ròmais
Rinn thu ghlacadh ad chrògan ,
Is bhith ’ ga stailceadh le t ’ òrdaig
Ann ad chabdheudach sgòrach ;
’ S reamhar farsaing do sgòrnan , 1385
Brù mar chuilean an òtraich ;
Fhuair thu urram nan geòcach ri d ’ bheò ,
Fhuair thu urram &c .

Bidh na mnathan ag ràite ,
’ N uair a rachadh tu ’ n àirigh , 1390
Gun tolladh tu ’ n t - àros
Anns am bitheadh an càise ;
’ N uair a dh ’ itheadh tu pàirt deth ,
’ S a bhiodh tu air tràsgadh ,
Anns a ’ mhuidhe gun spàrr thu do chròg , 1395
Anns a ’ mhuidhe &c .
[Beurla]

Cochull glogach mu t ’ àrainn ,
Tha do sgamhan is t ’ àinean
Làn galair is fàslaich is chòs ,
Làn galair &c .

Beul do chléibh air a thachdadh , 1405
Air séideadh ’ s air brachadh ,
’ S e gu h - éidigh air malcadh ,
’ S mór fheum air a chartadh ;
Gach aon eucail ad phearsain ,
Caitheamh , éitich is casdaich , 1410
Gus an d ’ éirich do chraiceann o t ’ fheòil ,
Gus an d ’ éirich &c .

Tha do chreuchdan ’ s do chuislean
Làn eucail is trusdair ,
’ S thu feumach air furtachd ; 1415
Tha ’ n déideadh ad phluicean ,
’ S tu ’ d éigin le clupaid ;
T ’ anail bhreun gu trom murtaidh ,
’ S mairg a dh ’ fheuchadh dhìot mochthrath do thòchd ,
’ S mairg a dh ’ fheuchadh &c . 1420

Do dheud sgròbbhearnach cabach
A bheil na sgòirfhiaclan glasa ,
Mosgain còsacha sgealpach ,
Lùbte grannda cam feacta ,
A null ’ s a nall air an tarsainn , 1425
Cuid diubh caillt ’ air dol asad ,
’ S na bheil ann diubh air spagadh do bheòil ,
’ S na bheil ann &c .
[Beurla]

’ S dorcha doilleir do chlisneach ,
Cho dubh ris a ’ phice ;
Uchd na curra , ceann circ ’ ort , gob geòidh , 1435
Uchd na curra , &c .

Do mhaol chnuacach air faileadh ,
Gun chluasan gun fhaillean ;
Tha thu uainealach tana ,
Cho cruaidh ris an darach , 1440
’ S tu gun suanach gun anart ;
’ S adhbhar truais thu ri d ’ ghearan ,
’ S gur fuair ’ thu na gailleann an reòt ’ ,
’ S gur fuair ’ thu &c .

Tha ceann binneach ’ na stùic ort , 1445
Geocach lethcheannach giùgach ;
Aodann brucanach gnùgach ,
Sròn phlucach na mùire ;
Tha cruit air do chùlaibh ,
’ S móran lurcaich ad ghlùinibh ; 1450
Dà chois chama chaol chrùbach , gun treòir ,
Dà chois chama &c .

Chan ’ eil uiread nan sàiltean
Aig a ’ phliutaire spàgach ,
Nach ’ eil cuspach is gàgach , 1455
Tha thu ’ d chrioplach ’ s ad chràigeach :
’ S lìonmhor tubaist an tàilleir ,
Dh ’ fhàg an saoghal ’ na thràill e ,
’ S mairg a shaothraich air t ’ àrach ’ s tu òg ,
’ S mairg a shaothraich &c . 1460
[Beurla]

Cha tig cobhair gu bràth ort , 1465
Gus am foghainn am bàs duit ,
’ S do chorp odhar a chàradh fo ’ n fhòid ,
’ S do chorp odhar &c .
[Beurla]
’ S nighean mo ghaoil &c .
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

’ S a ’ chaora fhuair mi o Shiùsaidh
Gun an cùinn a dhol g ’ a ceannach .
Hem ó , ho ió , &c . 1865
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

Togamaid fonn air luadh a ’ chlòthlain , 2025
Gabhaidh sinn ceòl is òrain mhatha .
Ho ró gun togainn &c .
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

’ S mi teàrnadh a Coir ’ a ’ Cheathaich ,
’ S mór mo mhìghean ’ s mi gun aighear ,
Siubhal frìthe ré an latha : 2175
Thilg mi ’ n spraigh nach d ’ rinn feum dhomh .
Chunnaic mi ’ n damh donn &c .

’ N uair chaidh mi do Ghleann Lòchaidh ,
’ S a cheannaich mi Nic Còiseim ,
Is mise nach robh gòrach
’ N uair chuir mi ’ n t - òr g ’ a fuasgladh .
Hóro , mo chuid chuideachd thu , &c . 3330
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

Ged a tha sinn car tamaill
A ’ tàmh aig na Gallaibh ,
Tha mo dhùthaich air m ’ aire , 3385
’ S cha mhath leam a h - àicheadh .
Horinn ó ho irir ìo , &c .

B ’ annsa leat an stòp ;
Chan e sin bu docha
Ach am botal mór .
Alasdair nan stòp , &c .

Mo bheannachd aig na balgairean , 5020
A chionn bhith sealg nan caorach .
Ho hù o hó na balgairean , &c .
[Beurla]
[Beurla]

Ghabh mi tàmh air thùs
Ann an seòrsa de thaigh ùdlaidh ,
Is rinn mi suidhe sùmhail
Gus ’ n do mhùth mi cairtealan .
Is rinn mi suidhe sùmhail , &c . 5075

In Sàr Obair , p . 238 , there is a story that the banker received the poem very ungraciously and refused to pay the expected fee on the ground that the ode was but a record of fact , and that in any case the authorship was in doubt . Challenged to compose a song of dispraise , the poet ( according to Sàr Obair ) began “ in the same measure , ” and this is the stanza quoted in F , p . 494* :

An oidhche bha mi an Tigh na Sràid†
Fhuair mi tàmailt a bha mór ,
Fhuair mi stràc de ’ n bhata chaol
Bho Iain claon an Achadh Mhóir . ‡
* But see quotation from Records of Argyll in the Introduction , p . xxvi .
† Killin Hotel .
‡ The house of Auchmore , near Killin .

O ’ s ioma fear goiseid ( gòirseid )
Le ghuna boidheach ’ s lann du - ghorm ,
Le ’ n cuinnseiribh caola ,
’ S an taidhmin ’ gan giùlan …

Here an taidhmin = an taidhmean , their “ straps , ” supporting the whingers . ( For the forms taoim , taidhm , cf . maoim , maidhm ; snaoim , snaidhm . ) Thus taoim appears to be the link between the dirk - sheath and waist - belt — a link or chain , a cord or strap . Cf . also Gillies , p . 299 :
Crios do leathar na ’ n aighin / Ceann leathann is deadh thaim air .

Mr Matheson suggests a possible connection with Eng . team , * which meant ( a ) part of a gear by which oxen or horses were harnessed to a plough , ( b ) a strong iron chain , chain in general ; or development , by normal loss of final vowel , from tuidme , act of fastening , fixing , binding ; tuidhme = coimhcheangal , O ’ Cl . ( RIA Dict . , Contribb . ) ; tuidhme , binding together , union ( Dinn ) ; tuidhme , confederacy , conjunction ( Dwelly ) ; tuidhmim , I yoke , couple ( Lhuyd ) .
* Cf . W . Fris . team , bridle ; Dutch toom , bridle ; etc .

Tha e méineach iochdmhor bàidheil
Tròcaireach càirdeach , làn athtruais ,
Guineach ri naimhdean ’ sna blàraibh
Gus an tàradh e fo smachd iad .

[He is tender , humane , kindly ,
merciful , friendly , full of pity ,
fierce against his foes in battles ,
till he accomplished their subjection .

Blessing from these stripped , poor folk of Moidart ,
blessing from each place goes with you ,
since you drove none of them , with harshness ,
old or young , away as outcasts . ]

Duncan took his wife to Lismore and lived there for months , working with MacNicol at the poems … They quarrelled at last regarding a poem — The

1297 . “ Ecclesiastical authority over the morals of the community was wielded in the early part of the century ( 18th ) with almost undisputed sway . … Every rumour , every suspicion of ill - doing was reported to the Kirk - Session , and evidence of the most inquisitive kind was taken . … Immorality was rife … and culprits had to pay their fines , graduated according to the heinousness and frequency of the offence … Offenders stood ‘ at the pillory ’ — a raised platform or a stool in front of the pulpit , clad in a cloak of sackcloth — … and there to be admonished by the minister . ” ( Soc . text.p: “ As a young man , the bard … fell in love with a young girl of higher station and easier circumstances than his own . Her father , Robert Campbell , Claisgour , Blackmount , was an under - factor and freeholder . … ”

According to Dr Calder she was said to be “ a relation of the poet … in a somewhat better social position than her lover . Her father , a petty bailiff as well as keeper of a small wayside inn , which was later replaced by Inveroran Hotel , was named Nicol MacIntyre . ” ( F , p . xxvii . )

The latter account agrees with local tradition . The poet informs us that Màiri was descended from the men of Sleat , and in another poem he refers to the carpenter of Sleat as the eponym of the Macintyres . * She was evidently a serious - minded girl , gracious in manner , kindly in disposition and handsome in presence ; and she proved to be a devoted helpmeet to the poet , first in their humble Highland cottage , and later in Edinburgh .
* See also p . xxxv .

text.p: The reference to Culloden is of some interest as a contemporary reference to the part played by the MacDonalds in the battle . The poet merely says that the right wing “ was taken from them , ” implying that they claimed or expected to be placed on the right . There is here no suggestion that they declined to advance as stated by Chambers ( History of the Rebellion , p . 297 ) : “ … the Macdonalds withheld themselves on account of their removal to the left wing . According to the report of one of their officers , the clan not only resented this indignity , but considered it as omening evil fortune for the day . … ”

E . g .
Tha aodach coltach r ’ a obair ,
His clothes are suitable for his work .

In an age that had little coin in circulation the loss of even a small hoard was serious . In the first half of the ( 18th ) century coins “ were not sufficient for the currency needs of the country ; gold was never seen ; silver was exceedingly scarce , especially after all the Scots coinage had been called in subsequent to the Union . In default of Scots or English money , foreign coins were in ready use , and money which came from Holland , Spain and France was welcome . …

“ Leg - dollars , rix - dollars , guilders , ducatoons were of service as home currency . ” [Soc . Hist . Scot . , p . 31 . ] A Leg - dollar was equivalent to £2 16s . Scots , and a rix - dollar to £2 18s . Scots . At the time of the Union £1 Scots was worth 1s . 8d .

2749 . còrr = carra - meille ( orobus tuberosus ) , according to Plant Names , p . 22 .

The Highlanders have a great esteem for the tubercles of the roots ; they dry them and chew them to give a better relish to their whisky . They also affirm that they are good against most diseases of the thorax , and that by the use of them they are enabled to repel hunger and thirst for a long time . In Breadalbane and Ross - shire they sometimes bruise them and steep them in water , and make an agreeable fermented liquor with them , called cairm . …

Is paidearan geal dlùth - chneap

The metrical unit may be represented by ( P + n x Q ) , where n is a variable number , P a quatrain of rhyming couplets , and Q a strophic stanza , the last line of which rhymes with the couplets of P .
In ùrlar , n is 3 as a rule ; P has the formula 2 ( 5¹ + 5² ) ; and Q is of the form ( 3 x 5¹ + 5² ) .
In siubhal , n is variable ; P has the formula 2 ( 6² + 6² ) ; and Q , ( 3 x 6² + 6² ) .
In crùnludh , n is 7 in the first group and 4 in the others ; P has the formula 2 ( 8³ + 7² ) , and Q has the form ( 3 x 8³ + 7¹ ) .

laoidhre = ladhaire or ladhra , gen . of ladhar ( 1 ) cleft in hoof ; hoof , toe ; ( 2 ) natural fork or promontory , land between two converging rivers or hills ( Dinn . ) . On the six - inch map the shape of the area between the two streams may certainly be described as a shank terminating in a hoof .

Derivation from mearach + dasach or from mear + cas presents phonetic and semantic difficulties . Mr Angus Matheson suggests that form and meanings may be explained by the compound , mearghus ( mear + gus ) , which would yield mearghusach > mearchasach or meargasach > mearcasach . ( See RIA dict under mergus . )

Rannaigheachd dialtach , 2 ( 7¹ + 7¹ ) 2 + 4 , but many lines do not fit the syllabic formula . In stressed metre the poem is an òran with rhyming couplets ; each line has three stresses , and the last stressed vowel of the first line assonates with the middle ( or the first , in three instances ) stressed vowel of the second line . The first syllable of the couplet bears the stress . Thus the reading chuir sinne in 3548 must be rejected .

1781
“ The Highland Society of London … being desirous that the ancient spirit of the Great Pipe … should be revived ,

“ Some gentlemen as a deputation from the Society at Glasgow , and the agent from Edinburgh , made their appearance at Falkirk , the day preceding that appointed for the competition . They met on the following morning , and adjourned to the Mason Lodge ; when , after hearing an excellent Gaelic poem recited by an old grey - headed bard , ( which he composed for the occasion ) , in the presence of a select company of ladies and gentlemen , thirteen competing Pipers , and the maker of the Prize Pipes , the deputation and the agent proceeded to the election of a preses , and six gentlemen to be judges of the merits of the performers . … The competitors were conducted to a room … where they … drew lots for priority of performance . This done , the person who drew lot No . 1 was conducted by a private door , to a small court below the windows of the lodge , in such a manner that the judges could neither see nor know the particular performer . Each person was made to play four different tunes . …

“ The judges almost unanimously awarded the first prize to Patrick MacGregor , Piper to Henry Balnaves , Esq . of Adradour , in the parish of Mullin and county of Perth ; the second prize to Charles MacArthur , Piper to the Earl of Eglinton ; and the third to John MacGregor , senior , aged 73 , Piper to Lt . - Col . John Campbell of Glenlyon . … ”

Oct . 1782
“ The competition for the prizes given annually by the Highland Society of London , for the encouragement of performers on the ancient martial instrument of Scotland , was determined by a select jury of gentlemen , in the presence of a numerous and respectable audience . After a long trial … the first prize was voted to John MacAlister , first piper to the West Fencible Regiment ; the second to John MacGregor , the father , then 74 years of age ; and the third to John MacGregor the son . ”

of Airds ; the second prize to Archibald MacGregor , fourth son of John MacGregor , Piper to Colonel Campbell of Glenlyon , and the third to John MacGregor , Piper to the City Guard of Edinburgh . The bard Ma can T ’ sior* was introduced , and pronounced his annual Gaelic poem , in praise of the martial music and prowess of the Caledonians . … On the return of the pipers from Falkirk by Edinburgh , it was conceived by many gentlemen , that an exhibition of their abilities would be a very agreeable entertainment to the public ; it was accordingly arranged that it should take place in Dunn ’ s Assembly Rooms . … During one of the intervals , the Bard Donn MacIntyre , in the City Guard , was introduced , who repeated a poem in the Gaelic , in praise of that language and ancient music of the great Pipes , which was much approved of by those who understood that language . ”

“ By 1770 there were signs … of the approaching transformation of Edinburgh . … The town which had remained within its ancient bounds and walls for 250 years was becoming too circumscribed for its population . … About 1760 there had been erected squares of self - contained houses south of the town . … In 1772 the North Bridge was finished . … Plans by that time had been formed for streets on the other side of the ‘ Nor ’ Loch ’ ( the lake or swamp now the Princes Street Gardens ) , but slow progress was made till 1780 . …

“ Town and town life underwent a revolution . … The sedan chairs were becoming worn out , like the chairmen who had carried in them so many fair occupants . … The chairs were being discarded for hackney coaches that drove swiftly along handsome though unfinished streets . ” ( Soc . Life Scot . , p . 124 )
Couplets of the form ( 7³ + 6¹ ) rhyme throughout the stanza .

Bu toigh leat bardan a ’ s pìobrain ,
’ S i do chis nach biodh suarach .
( Turner ( 1813 ) , p . 233 )

The change from the stunted , delicate Highland sheep to larger and sturdier breeds that yielded more meat and wool was in progress by the middle of the eighteenth century . Sheep farms extended into hilly country where deer used to roam ; and as shelter for stock could be found only in the glens , many small crofting communities had to leave their homes . These clearances aroused bitter resentment , especially as many of the flock masters and their shepherds were Lowlanders . Extravagant expectations of profits from wool led to a great increase in rents which the ordinary farmer could not pay . The general effect on Highland economy was summed up in the prophecy — cuiridh a ’ chaora mhaol an crann air an fharadh .

Ciod am fàth dhomh bhith ’ g innse

text.p: ( Numbers refer to lines of text . OS = Ordnance Survey . )
The following list* gives names in English form as recorded by Dowie :
* To this list we have to add Ruadh Aisridh ( 2302 ) , a small burn on the west side of Coire a ’ Cheathaich .

Turning north through Auch Glen and following the old track by Allt Chonghlais ( River Auch ) we note three burns ( not named in Map B ) flowing down the south - eastern slope of the ben . At the head of the first is Coire Fhraoich ( 3178 ) ; the second rises in Coire a ’ Chruiteir* ( 2844 ) — Coire Chruitein in OS ; and the third , draining the southern face of Meall Teanail ( 3129 ) — Meall Tionail in Map B — is Allt na h - annaid ( 3130 ) . The chapel ( annaid ) and the burial ground were situated in the northern angle of the confluence of this tributary with the Auch . Craobh na h - Ainnis ( 3106 ) , according to tradition , stood on the opposite bank of the Auch at this point . ( See F , pp . 511 , 531 . )

* The name Coire a ’ Chruiteir has been rather fancifully explained by reference to the twanging sounds made by certain winds in the corrie ; but the OS form of the name is modern and may have been suggested by a name like Gleann Cruitean , Oban .
